title: Avio Reveals More Hardware for its FD1 Rocket Demonstrator
summary:
As part of its nine-month 2025 financial report, Italian rocket builder Avio shared images of several flight components for its FD1 rocket demonstrator, including the fairing, propellant tanks, avionics, and interstage. In early October, Avio announced the successful completion of a static fire test of its MR10 DMX2 LOX-methane rocket engine. According to the company, […]
The post Avio Reveals More Hardware for its FD1 Rocket Demonstrator appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Italian rocket builder Avio shared images of several flight components for its FD1 rocket demonstrator, including the fairing, propellant tanks, avionics, and interstage. Avio announced the successful completion of a static fire test of its MR10 DMX2 LOX-methane rocket engine in early October.

title: AI challenge advances satellite-based disaster mapping
summary: Four teams from different countries have been recognised for their breakthrough work in using artificial intelligence to detect earthquake damage from space, marking the conclusion of a global competition organised by the European Space Agency in collaboration with the International Charter ‘Space and Major Disasters’ – commonly referred to as ‘the Charter’.
detailed_news: Four teams from different countries have been recognised for their breakthrough work in using artificial intelligence to detect earthquake damage from space. The winning teams – TelePIX from the Republic of Korea, Datalayer from Belgium, DisasterM3 from Japan and Thales Services Numériques from France – were honoured recently during a ceremony held at the Charter’s 54th Board Meeting in Strasbourg. The competition was organised by the European Space Agency in collaboration with the International Charter ‘Space and Major Disasters’ The European finalists stood out for their cutting-edge approaches. Participants faced challenges similar to real-world emergency operations. Datalayer leveraged scalable, cloud-based machine learning pipelines. Thales Services Numériques applied deep-learning and trustworthy-AI techniques to pinpoint structural damage with precision.

summary:

title: ESA’s first stand-alone deep-space CubeSat Henon takes shape
summary: The European Space Agency’s upcoming Henon mission will be the first ever CubeSat to independently venture into deep space, communicate with Earth and manoeuvre to its final destination without relying on a bigger spacecraft. Once in its orbit around the Sun, the carry-on luggage-sized CubeSat will observe the Sun’s emissions to demonstrate technologies capable of providing advanced warnings of solar storms hours before they reach Earth.
detailed_news: ESA’s Heliospheric Pioneer for Solar and Interplanetary Threats Defence, Henon for short, is set to be the first ever stand-alone CubeSat to perform significant manoeuvres on the way to its far-away destination. Henon is expected to piggyback on the launch of a larger spacecraft planned for late 2026. The launcher will take the CubeSat 1.5 million km beyond Earth in the direction away from the Sun. The Henon mission is being developed with funding from ESA’s General Support Technology Programme (GSTP) The CubeSat will use its new electric propulsion system to fly to a Distant Retrograde Orbit (DRO) around the Sun. Henon will be the first ever spacecraft to fly in this type of orbit, which will take it 12 million km from Earth at its closest point, and 24 million km away at the farthest.

summary:
European Space Agency Director General Josef Aschbacher unveiled the European Resilience from Space programme on Tuesday in Brussels. The initiative aims to pool national space assets and develop new capabilities in intelligence, surveillance, secure communications, and navigation to strengthen Europe’s resilience and autonomy in the face of emerging security threats. It is expected to have […]
The post ESA Proposes €1B Budget to Align European Space Capabilities for Defence appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: European Space Agency Director General Josef Aschbacher unveiled the European Resilience from Space programme on Tuesday in Brussels. The initiative aims to pool national space assets and develop new capabilities in intelligence, surveillance, secure communications, and navigation. It is expected to have a budget of €1 billion.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 29 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral
summary: This is just the second time that SpaceX opted to launch 29 of its Starlink V2 Mini satellites in one batch, the current limit for the Falcon 9 rocket. Liftoff of the Starlink 10-37 mission from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station is scheduled for 12:16 p.m. EDT (1616 UTC).
detailed_news: The Starlink 10-37 mission will carry 29 of the company’s Starlink V2 Mini Optimized satellites into low Earth orbit. Liftoff from Space Launch Complex 40 is scheduled for 12:16 p.m. EDT (1616 UTC) The 45th Weather Squadron forecast a 95 percent chance for favorable weather during the launch window.

title: Blue Origin details lunar exploration progress amid Artemis 3 contract shakeup
summary: The company’s senior director of civil space shared the progress on their crew and cargo Blue Moon landers during the American Astronautical Society’s 2025 von Braun Space Exploration Symposium.
detailed_news: Blue Origin CEO Dave Limp shared a 17-minute-long video of one hot fire test in Texas meant to simulate the Apogee Raise Maneuver for the Blue Moon Mark 1 lander. The company is also developing plans that could expedite the Artemis 3 mission, which will be the first human landing on the Moon as part of NASA’s Artemis program. Blue Origin plans to recover the first stage booster flying on the upcoming EscaPADE mission for NASA and then reuse it for the first flight of a Blue Moon Mk. 1 lander. Last month, NASA tapped Blue Origin as the vehicle that will deliver its VIPER (Volatiles Investigating Polar Exploration Rover) mission to the Moon. SpaceX was granted a $2.89 billion contract for the Artemis 3 mission in April 2021. The company completed 11 integrated test flights of its Starship-Super Heavy rocket and is preparing to transition to the third major version of the launch vehicle. Aarti Matthews, Director of Starship Crew and Cargo Programs at SpaceX, wasn’t present to represent the company. Vote for your favorite SpaceX mission in the weekly Newsquiz. Send your photos and videos to iReport.com. Visit the Daily Discussion to share your photos, videos and stories. The Daily Discussion is edited for grammar and punctuation. Use the weeklyNewsquiz to test your knowledge of stories you saw on Spaceflight Now.

title: Starbase Pad 1 demolition begins for Next-Gen upgrades

authors.name: Alejandro Alcantarilla Romera and Chris Bergin

summary:
SpaceX has kicked off a significant demolition and upgrade phase at its Starbase facility, targeting…
The post Starbase Pad 1 demolition begins for Next-Gen upgrades appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX has kicked off a significant demolition and upgrade phase at its Starbase facility, targeting Pad 1. The work, which began shortly after the successful Flight 11 mission, involves dismantling key components of the launch infrastructure to accommodate Version 3 Starships and Super Heavy boosters. The demolition efforts started with the iconic “chopsticks’ of the “Mechazilla system” – the massive mechanical arms on the launch tower used for catching and stacking boosters and ships. The Orbital Launch Mount (OLM) at Pad 1 will be the most visually prominent element of deconstruction. Work is already underway, removing several of the internal components such as piping, wiring, valves, and other components. Demolition extends to the tank farm, where Pad 1’s outdated subcoolers, pumps, and auxiliary hardware are being dismantled.

title: Melissa strikes Jamaica, tied as most powerful Atlantic storm to come ashore
summary: The storm was so strong a hurricane hunter had to end its mission early.
detailed_news: Hurricane Melissa made landfall in southwestern Jamaica, near New Hope, on Tuesday at 1 pm ET. The storm was so strong a hurricane hunter had to end its mission early. By strengthening overnight and then maintaining its incredible intensity of 185 mph, Melissa has tied the Labor Day Hurricane of 1935 as the most powerful hurricane to strike a landmass in the Atlantic Basin.

summary: The role of space for security was presented at a high-level event in Brussels on Tuesday.
detailed_news: The role of space for security was presented at a high-level event in Brussels on Tuesday. European Commissioner for Defence and Space Andrius Kubilius set the stage for discussions on the potential for space to support security. ESA Director General Josef Aschbacher presented the European Resilience from Space programme.

title: Astrobotic delays Griffin-1 Moon mission to NET July 2026
summary: The mission will carry a pair of commercial, robotic rovers to the lunar surface. It was most recently scheduled to launch by the end 2025.
detailed_news: Astrobotic is targeting the summer of 2026 for the launch of its second mission with the goal of landing on the surface of the Moon. The company based in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, said it was targeting a launch window in July 2026. Both missions are part of NASA’s Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS) program. Astrobotic’s Peregrine lunar lander was unpacked inside a clean room on the Space Coast. United Launch Alliance called off a test-firing of the first flight-rated Vulcan Centaur rocket at Cape Canaveral Thursday. The first payload teed up for NASA’S industry-led missions to the Moon has arrived in Florida.

title: ESA Expands Global Presence with First Office in Japan
summary:
The European Space Agency has announced the opening of its first satellite office in Japan as the agency looks to deepen its cooperation with the country. Japan and Europe’s space cooperation predates even ESA, with the country collaborating with the European Space Research Organisation, one of the agency’s precursor organisations. The Cooperation in Space Exploration […]
The post ESA Expands Global Presence with First Office in Japan appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: The European Space Agency has opened its first satellite office in Japan. The office is located in the X-Nihonbashi Tower, which is marketed as a ‘space business co-creation hub’ Japan and Europe’s space cooperation predates even ESA, with the country collaborating with the European Space Research Organisation.

title: The Red Spider Nebula, caught by Webb
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: NGC 6537 is a planetary nebula with a rich backdrop of thousands of stars. Planetary nebulae form when ordinary stars like the Sun reach the end of their lives. After ballooning into cool red giants, these stars shed their outer layers and cast them into space. Ultraviolet light from the central star ionises the cast-off material, causing it to glow.

title: ESA establishes presence in Tokyo to strengthen strategic partnership with Japan
summary: The European Space Agency has announced it is establishing a new presence in Tokyo, Japan, its first in Asia.
detailed_news: European Space Agency to establish a new presence in Tokyo, Japan. Will work to deepen cooperation with the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) Will be based at X-NIHONBASHI Tower, a hub for start-ups, academia and government agencies. The ESA-Japan relationship stands as a cornerstone of global space cooperation. With common interests and shared challenges – including sustainable use of space, climate monitoring, and fostering a competitive space economy – the two countries share a close relationship. The ESA and Japan Space Agency have been working together for more than 20 years.

title: Hurricane Melissa barrels through the Caribbean
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: The image was captured by the Copernicus Sentinel-3 mission on 26 October 2025. It shows the ‘brightness temperature’ at the top of Hurricane Melissa as it barrelled through the Caribbean Sea. The temperature of the surrounding ocean is much warmer, reaching as high as 25°C.

title: Watch live: Sentinel-1D launch on Ariane 6
summary: The Copernicus Sentinel-1 mission is about to get its fourth satellite, with Sentinel-1D now ready for liftoff. Launch will take place with an Ariane 6 rocket from Kourou, French Guiana and live coverage will be shown on Tuesday, 4 November, at 22:03 CET (18:03 at Kourou).
detailed_news: Launch will take place with an Ariane 6 rocket from Kourou, French Guiana. Watch live on ESA Web TV on Tuesday, 4 November 2025 (all times in CET) The Sentinel-1 mission delivers radar images of Earth’s surface, performing in all weathers, day-and-night.

title: Launch Roundup: China to launch crew to Tiangong, India to launch new naval satellite
summary:
Six missions comprise the worldwide launch manifest this week, including a crewed launch from China…
The post Launch Roundup: China to launch crew to Tiangong, India to launch new naval satellite appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Six missions comprise the worldwide launch manifest this week, including a crewed launch from China and a new naval satellite for the Indian Navy. SpaceX is set to kick off the week with three back-to-back Starlink missions from its pads in California and Florida. Later in the week, China will launch the crewed Shenzhou 21 mission to the Tiangong space station. Starlink Group 11-23 is set to launch from SLC-4E at Vandenberg on Thursday, Oct. 30. 28 Starlink v2 Mini satellites will be launched into a 53.16-degree-inclination LEO. Falcon booster B1063 will support the mission, flying on its 29th mission after a 32-day turnaround. The final Falcon 9 mission of the week is scheduled to be the rideshare Bandwagon-4 mission. The Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO) is scheduled to launch the CMS-03 mission atop its Launch Vehicle Mark-3 (LVM-3) rocket on Sunday, Nov. 2, at 10:30 UTC. The payload on this mission is the GSAT-7R satellite, specifically designed for the Indian Navy. This mission will mark the 140th Falcon 9 mission of 2025, and SpaceX’s 585th mission of all time.

summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: The Copernicus Sentinel-1D satellite has been encapsulated inside the Ariane 6 fairing at Europe's Spaceport in French Guiana. The mission operates in all weathers, day-and-night, to deliver high-resolution radar images of Earth’s surface.

title: Melissa set to be the strongest hurricane to ever strike Jamaica
summary: Storm reached sustained winds of 160 mph on Monday morning.
detailed_news: Storm reached sustained winds of 160 mph on Monday morning. Storm will make landfall in southern Jamaica less than 24 hours from now. Will almost certainly be the strongest tropical system to strike Jamaica in more than 150 years of records. Storm also poses lesser threats to Hispaniola, the Bahamas, and potentially Bermuda down the line.

The agreement, signed on 24 October, will also see the transfer of responsibility for the development of theAriane 6 oxygen turbopump from Avio’s headquarters in Colleferro to Vernon.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 28 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from California
summary: This will be the 98th launch of Starlink satellites in 2025. SpaceX is targeting liftoff of the Starlink 11-21 mission from pad 4E at Vandenberg Space Force Base, California, at 2:12 p.m. PDT (5:12 p.m. EDT / 2112 UTC).
detailed_news: The Starlink 11-21 mission will add another 28 more of the V2 Mini iteration of the satellites into low Earth orbit. An on-time liftoff would break the record for the fastest pad turnaround for SpaceX’s West Coast launch pad. The company has already set turnaround records this month on both coasts. This will be its 17th flight following USSF-62, NROL-145, OneWeb Launch 20 and 13 batches of Starlink satellites.

title: What’s Happening in Space Policy October 26-November 1, 2025
summary: Here is SpacePolicyOnline.com’s list of space policy events for the week of October 26-November 1, 2025 and any insight we can offer about them.  The Senate is in session this […]
detailed_news: SpacePolicyOnline.com's list of space policy events for the week of October 26-November 1, 2025. The Senate is in session this week. The House continues to be in recess indefinitely except for pro forma sessions. Both sides are wagering the public will blame the other as federal workers and contractors increase their credit card debt. JAXA launched the first of its new HTV cargo ships, HTV-X1, to the ISS. It will dock at the ISS on Wednesday. Another Russian spacewalk will take place the day before (Tuesday) China is getting ready to launch a new crew, Shenzhou-21, to their Tiangong-3.  Daylight Saving Time ends in the United States next Sunday morning at 2:00 am. Europe and the UK “fell back” today to Central European Time (CET) and Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) Those and other events we know about as of Sunday morning are shown below. Check back throughout the week for others we learn about later and add to our Calendar.

title: JAXA’s HTV-X1 set to launch to ISS aboard H3 Rocket
summary:
The Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) is set to launch its advanced HTV-X1 cargo spacecraft…
The post JAXA’s HTV-X1 set to launch to ISS aboard H3 Rocket appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: The Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) is set to launch its advanced HTV-X1 cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station (ISS) from the Yoshinobu Launch Complex at Tanegashima Space Center on Sunday. The launch had been delayed for days due to poor weather at the picturesque launch site. The mission will utilize JAXA’s H3-24L rocket. The HTV-X1 is designed to deliver cargo to Gateway, a planned lunar-orbiting space station in a near-rectilinear halo orbit. JAXA is also contributing to Gateway through the International Habitation (I-Hab) module, developed in collaboration with the European Space Agency. The H3 rocket debuted in March 2023 with the launch of the 3.7-tonne ALOS-3 satellite.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 28 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral
summary: This will be the 230th launch of Starlink V2 Mini satellites to date. SpaceX is targeting liftoff of the Starlink 10-21 mission from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station during a window that opens at 10:05 a.m. EDT (1405 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is preparing for a Sunday morning Falcon 9 launch from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station to fly more of its Starlink broadband internet satellites into low Earth orbit. The 45th Weather Squadron forecast a 85 percent chance for favorable weather at the opening of the window, but noted that it decreases to 70 percent favorability as the window progresses. The primary concern for meteorologists are cumulus clouds.

title: Unions’ Reactions Mixed to Airbus, Thales, and Leonardo Merger
summary:
With the announcement that Airbus, Thales, and Leonardo have signed a memorandum of understanding to combine their space businesses into a single company, trade unions representing the affected workers have given mixed reactions to the news. The project, which, while not officially named, has been referred to by media sources as Project Bromo, would combine […]
The post Unions’ Reactions Mixed to Airbus, Thales, and Leonardo Merger appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Airbus, Thales, and Leonardo have signed a memorandum of understanding to combine their space businesses into a single company. Trade unions representing the affected workers have given mixed reactions to the news. The sharpest criticism came from FTM-CGT, the metalworkers’ federation of the Confédération générale du travail. title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 28 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg SFB
summary: The mission is poised to featured the 160th landing of a booster on the drone ship, ‘Of Course I Still Love You’. Liftoff from pad 4E at Vandenberg Space Force Base is scheduled for 7:20 a.m. PDT (10:20 a.m. EDT / 1420 UTC).
detailed_news: The Starlink 11-12 mission will add another 28 broadband satellites to the constellation of more than 8,700 spacecraft in low Earth orbit. This will be its 135 Falcon 9 launch of 2025, breaking its record number of orbital launches achieved in all of 2024. The mission comes nearly a week after SpaceX launched its 10,000th Starlink satellite to date.

title: Starbase Pad 1 ends an era, enters preparations for the next phase
summary:
After 11 Flights and many tests, the booster test stand turned launch mount has reached…
The post Starbase Pad 1 ends an era, enters preparations for the next phase appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Pad 1 began construction in July 2020, when crews started laying the foundation for the six legs of the launch mount. The mount itself was built at the production site, then rolled to the launch site and installed on the legs on July 31, 2021. Pad 1 propelled the Starship program through the early years and now moves towards the new phase of operations. The booster test stand turned launch mount has reached the end of its life. The first-ever static fire on Pad 1 occurred on Aug 9, 2022, with a single engine test from Booster 7. The first stack of the first set of actual flight vehicles occurred on Oct 11, 2022. A Wet Dress Rehearsal was completed with Booster 7 and Ship 24 on Jan 23, 2023. A full-duration 10-second 33 engine static fire wouldn’t occur until Aug 25, 20 23, with Booster 9. Pad 1 performed 28 cryogenic proof and tanking tests, 15 spin primes, 34 static fires, six wet dress rehearsals, four aborted launch attempts, and 11 Full Stack flight tests. The quickest turnaround time for Pad 1 was 37 days between Flight 5 and Flight 6.
